overview_of_class: When we talk about "film music," we usually focus on scores for narrative fiction films, but music has also played a significant role - if often a controversial one - in non-fiction film since the very beginning of the cinema. This course will examine documentary films from a variety of periods and approaches to the genre, as well as films initially presented as documentary that now appear to us as propaganda. Some of the material to be addressed may include the "actuality" shorts and "city symphony" films of the silent era; Depression-era documentaries scored by Virgil Thomson and Aaron Copland; World War II propaganda from the United States (the Why We Fight newsreel series), England (Humphrey Jennings's Listen to Britain), and Nazi Germany (Leni Riefenstahl's Triumph of the Will); rock documentaries of the 1960s directed by D.A. Pennebaker (Don't Look Back) and David and Albert Maysles (Gimme Shelter); Philip Glass's scores of the 1980s to films by Godfrey Reggio (Koyanisqaatsi) and Errol Morris (The Thin Blue Line); and related media such as news and "reality TV." In all cases, we will consider both the aesthetics of music in relation to the documentary image and the ethics of how music is employed to persuade the spectator and to impact the presentation of "reality" on screen.
